thread.title: High School Football: New Bedford strikes early, and often, in easy win over Barrington
thread.title_full: High School Football: New Bedford strikes early, and often, in easy win over Barrington

author: Ed Collins ecollins@s-t.com
title: High School Football: New Bedford strikes early, and often, in easy win over Barrington
text: Posted Oct. 10, 2015 at 5:26 PM Updated at 9:16 PM » Social News BARRINGTON, R.I. — New Bedford got off the bus scoring touchdowns Saturday morning in a 42-0 romp over Barrington at Victory Field. The Whalers struck for a touchdown on their first play from scrimmage when senior quarterback Andrew Rapoza hooked up with senior wide receiver Manny Onuoha for a 56-yard bomb that made it a 6-0 game just 17 seconds in. "We were looking to get off to a quick start and Andrew made a great throw," said Onuoha, who finished with four catches for 110 yards and three touchdowns. "If you run your route and get open, he's going to get you the ball and that play gave us some momentum right away. We came in ready to throw the ball and we made a statement with that first drive." New Bedford kept the pedal to the metal after that, scoring on four of its next six possessions to build a commanding 35-0 lead at halftime. The Eagles also bungled a second-quarter punt out of their own end zone when the snap sailed over the head of Colby Watson for a safety that gave the Whalers two points. Senior running back Jonathan Moraes rushed for a 12-yard touchdown and Rapoza ran in the two-point conversion to make it 14-0 after the first quarter. New Bedford put 21 more points on the board in the second quarter on a 19-yard pass to Onuoha, the safety, a 9-yard run by Victor Carrion and a 27-yard pass to Onuoha and an extra point by John Owens. That gave the Whalers a 35-0 halftime advantage and they capped their scoring with a 52-yard punt return by senior wide wide receiver/defensive back Jordan Ross with 9:22 left in the third quarter. The game was originally scheduled for Friday night, but it never got started because of lightning and was rescheduled for Saturday morning. "That knocked us off our routine a little bit, but we made sure everyone stayed focused on the task at hand," New Bedford coach Mark DeBrito said. "I was happy with our execution on both sides of the ball. We still have some things to work on, but we got the job done. We didn't have a lot of penalties and we were consistent from start to finish. We got off to a strong start and we finished strong." Rapoza, who played well for the second straight week after coming back from a concussion, completed 9-of-13 passes for 206 yards and three touchdowns. "He leads with his actions and he's been getting the job done all season," DeBrito said. "He sets the tone for us and his teammates have complete confidence in him. He makes good decisions with the ball, he's a tough runner and he has the ability to make a play no matter what the situation is. He's a talented, dangerous player and you can never count him out." WHAT IT MEANS: The win was the second straight for the Whalers (3-2, 0-0 Big 3 Conference), who notched an impressive 41-20 win at Barnstable last week and have outscored their last two opponents 83-20. ... The Eagles dropped to 0-6. They were outscored 40-18 in their first two games and have been shut out the last four weeks by a combined score of 171-0 in losses to La Salle (47-0), South Kingstown (47-0), Bishop Hendricken (35-0) and New Bedford (42-0). NEW BEDFORD STATS: The Whalers finished with 291 yards of total offense — 85 on the ground and 206 through the air. ... Moraes ran the ball four times for 41 yards and Rapoza had two rushes for 27 yards. ... Eli Conde caught three passes for 71 yards. ... Ross hauled in an 18-yard catch and Chandler Kuehne caught a five-yard pass. BARRINGTON STATS: The Eagles ran the ball 27 times for only 24 yards. They had negative yardage on 12 rushes. ... McManus completed 5-of-16 passes for 66 yards. ... Junior receiver David Kelly had a 30-yard pass reception and sophomore tight end Ryan Reed had a 19-yard catch. NOTES: Ross, who scored the first two touchdowns of his career in last week's 41-20 win at Barnstable, scored for the second straight week. .... Defensive lineman Matt Lopes and sophomore defensive lineman Victor Lopez had quarterback sacks for the Whalers. ... New Bedford also had a team sack in the fourth quarter. ... Onuoha and senior defensive back Eli Conde had interceptions. ... Junior linebacker Lucas Dillon had a second-quarter fumble recovery for the Eagles. ... Freshman backup quarterback Tru Williams played the second half for the Whalers. ... New Bedford's only punt of the game came with 1:30 left in the third quarter. ... In addition to the two extra-points that he made, Owens missed two other kicks and had one blocked. ... The game featured 12-minute quarters and the fourth quarter was played with running time. Rhode Island Interscholastic League rules call for that whenever a team leads by at least 35 points after three quarters. New Bedford 42, Barrington 0 Scoring NB — Andrew Rapoza 56 pass to Manny Onuoha (kick failed), 11:43 NB — Jonathan Moraes 12 run (Rapoza run), 6:17 Second Quarter NB — Rapoza 19 pass to Onuoha (kick failed), 11:53 NB — Barrington safety, 8:50 NB — Victor Carrion 9 run (kick blocked), 6:44 NB — Rapoza 27 pass to Onuoha (John Owens kick), 2:42 Third Quarter NB — Jordan Ross 52 punt return (Owens kick), 9:22 Fourth Quarter No scoring INDIVIDUAL STATISTICS RUSHING: NB — Moraes 4-41, Rapoza 2-27, Carrion 1-9, Caiden Varao 2-2, Tru Williams 1-4, Maraud Washington 1-3, Terrence Flood 1-1, Ross 1-(-1), Davelle Carreiro 1-(-1); B — Vasilios Meltsakos 10-16, Liam McManus 8-4, Evan Pomfret 7-2, Nicholas Roach 2-2. PASSING: NB — Rapoza 9-13-206; B — McManus 5-16-66. RECEIVING: NB — Onuoha 4-110, Eli Conde 3-71, Chandler Kuehne 1-7, Ross 1-18; B — Ryan Reed 1-19, Jacob Fontaine 1-5, Pomfret 1-4, David Kelley 1-30, Ian Fitzgerald 1-8. RECORDS: New Bedford (3-2, 0-0 Big 3 Conference); Barrington (0-6) By Ed Collins
